Definition: The rate of cooling (by expansion) as an air parcel rises. It is approximately 1 degrees Celsius per 100 metres. It is also the rate of heating (by compression) as an air parcel descends.
A large body of air that has similar temperature, pressure and moisture properties.
the pressure exerted by the atmosphere
elevation above sea level or above the earth's surface
High pressure system in which air descends to give calm conditions and clear skies. Associated with summer heatwaves and winter frosts and fogs.
the mass of air surrounding the Earth
The envelope of air surrounding the Earth and bound to it by gravity.
Pressure (force per unit area) exerted by the atmosphere on any surface by virtue of its weight.
the center around which something rotates
an instrument that measures atmospheric pressure
the regions of the Earth where living organisms exist
a storm with widespread snowfall accompanied by strong winds
a heavy odorless colorless gas formed during respiration and by the decomposition of organic substances; absorbed from the air by plants in photosynthesis
a temperature scale that defines the freezing point of water as 0 degrees and the boiling point of water as 100 degrees
free movement or passage
a wispy white cloud at a high altitude
Sky with a total cloud cover of less than one okta.
the weather in some location averaged over a period of time
a change in the world's climate
a visible mass of water or ice particles suspended at a considerable altitude
the front of an advancing mass of colder air
The "leading edge" of a relatively cold air mass.
atmospheric moisture that has changed from a gas
A climate with a high temperature range away from the influence of the sea. Winters will be colder and summers warmer compared to a coastal location for the same latitude.
a globular cloud
a steady flow of a fluid or gas
a periodically repeated sequence of events
a violent storm in which air moves in a circular direction

Area in the atmosphere in which the pressures are lower than those of the surrounding region at the same level. In its development a depression usually has the following phases. A wave (young) depression forms and moves along a front. Mature depressions have well-developed warm sectors and both cold and warm fronts. An occluded depression is that within which there has developed an occluded front.
a gradual transformation into arid, uninhabitable land
the temperature at which the water vapor in the air becomes saturated and condensation begins
a shortage of rainfall
distance of something above a reference point
an imaginary line around the Earth forming a great circle
The physical process by which a liquid or solid substance is transformed to a gas; the opposite of condensation.
of or relating to a temperature scale proposed by the inventor of the mercury thermometer
a temperature scale that defines the freezing point of water as 32 degrees and the boiling point of water a 212 degrees
a sudden local flood of great volume and short duration
Saturated air with visibility below one kilometre. Fog differs from cloud only in that the base of fog is at the Earth's surface while clouds are above the surface.
a prediction about how something will develop

The meeting point between two air masses of different density. Since the temperature is the most important regulator of the atmosphere density, a front almost invariably separates air masses of different temperature. When warmer air replaces the colder, it is a warm front, and a front is a cold one when the opposite occurs.
a slowly moving mass of ice
a rise in the average temperature of the earth's atmosphere
warming when solar radiation is trapped by the atmosphere
small pellet of ice that falls during a hailstorm
a form of energy transferred by a difference in temperature
a wave of unusually hot weather
wetness in the atmosphere
Water vapor content of the air.
a severe tropical cyclone usually with heavy rains and winds
any period of time during which glaciers covered a large part of the earth's surface
A line of equal or constant pressure. Measured in millibars (mb).
an imaginary line around the Earth parallel to the equator
an electric discharge between clouds or from cloud to earth
the angular distance from the prime meridian at Greenwich
A climate with a low temperature range influenced by proximity to the sea. Winters will be warmer and summers cooler compared to a continental location for the same latitude.
a specialist who studies processes in the earth's atmosphere that cause weather conditions
the earth science dealing with phenomena of the atmosphere
rainy season in southern Asia
A front that is formed as a cold front overtakes a warm front and lifts the warm air completely off the ground.
AÂ measure of cloud cover (in fractions of eight) on a synoptic chart.
a layer in the stratosphere (at approximately 20 miles) that contains a concentration of ozone sufficient to block most ultraviolet radiation from the sun
located at or coming from the earth's extremities

Any of all of the forms of water particles, whether liquid or solid, that fall from the atmosphere and reach the ground. The forms of precipitation are: rain, drizzle, snow, snow grains, snow pellets, diamond dust, hail, and ice pellets.
the force exerted by the atmosphere
The most common wind direction for a particular location.
gauge consisting of an instrument to measure the quantity of precipitation
an area that has little precipitation because some barrier causes the winds to lose their moisture before reaching it
Formed when air is forced to rise over relief features such as hills or mountains. Cooling and condensation occurs as the air rises.
man-made equipment that orbits around the earth or the moon
a cooling breeze from the sea (during the daytime)
level of the ocean's surface
one of the natural periods into which the year is divided by the equinoxes and solstices or atmospheric conditions
Periodic fluctuations in the climate related to seasons of the year e.g. wet winters, drier summers.
precipitation consisting of a mixture of rain and snow
A word currently used as a synonym for general air pollution. It was originally created by combining the words "smoke" and "fog.
relating to the sun or utilizing the energies of the sun
a large dark low cloud
A weather chart reflecting the state of the atmosphere over a large area at a given moment.
mild or free from extremes
the degree of hotness or coldness of a body or environment
Maximum minus the minimum temperature for a particular location.
measuring instrument for measuring temperature
property possessed by a line that departs from the vertical
a violently destructive windstorm occurring over land
relating to part of the Earth's surface with hot climate
a rain forest in a tropical area
all the plant life in a particular region or period
the front of an advancing mass of warmer air
The zone of warm air within a depression.
Water substance in vapour (gaseous) form; one of the most important of all constituents of the atmosphere.

The state of the atmosphere, mainly with respect to its effects upon life and human activities. As distinguished from climate, weather consists of the short-term (minutes to about 15 days) variations of the atmosphere state.
(meteorology) a map showing the principal meteorological elements at a given time and over an extended region
movement of air caused by changes in temperature and air pressure. Winds are always identified by the compass direction from which they blow.
mechanical device attached to an elevated structure
